Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Factors Influencing Police Reform and Global Police Designs

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Studies of policing have tended to focus locally on the relationships between police and the communities they serve. But the recent proliferation of global police designs across a diverse range of communities suggests the need for researchers to adapt their methodological approach. This project, which trains a graduate student in methods of empirical, scientific data collection and analysis, explores the different global, national, and local factors influencing police reform. It further asks, what new theoretical and methodological tools are necessary for studying policing - traditionally conceived as an arm of the state - as a transnational institution? Findings will be disseminated to organizations that manage and develop policy for improved policing. The research also fosters international scientific cooperation.

Eilat Maoz, under the supervision of Dr. Stephan Palmi√© of the University of Chicago, will explore what global, national, and local forces influence observable patterns in police reform. Police designs are informed by police knowledge, expertise, and practice, and increasingly these designs are shared internationally. The researcher proposes to document their implementation, and examine how they are engaged within the communities that they are implemented. The research will take place through ethnographic fieldwork in the Jamaican Constabulary Force (JCF). The JCF was established when Jamaica was Britain's most thriving sugar colony, as a highly militarized colonial police force. Today, excessive violence and rampant corruption, still endemic in the JCF, are seen as a colonial inheritance that can be superseded through systematic reform. Paradoxically, however, the reform process launched in 2008 deepens and extends foreign involvement within the Force, and is primarily designed to address global security agendas crafted abroad. A parallel dynamic of continuity and change characterizes Jamaica's socioeconomic configurations. While the socially stratified structure of Jamaican society was molded by its colonial history, the local meanings of difference are continuously refigured by global migrations and transnational cultural currents. This research seeks to understand the interaction between these two processes as they conjoin in the realm of police reform. In the first phase of this ethnographic study, Investigators will study how reform plans are crafted, disseminated, and implemented by the Force. This phase will include observing the operations of three branches of the JCF, participation in police training courses, and documentation of attempts to improve the relationship between the police and local communities. Observations within the force will be complemented by in-depth interviews with local and foreign security experts, to further understand the context, content, and specific goals of the reform as it is currently crafted. In the second phase, investigators will collaborate with two Jamaican NGOs that seek to address social violence and criminality in novel ways, bringing together public and private stakeholders, and extending the links between communities in Jamaica and abroad. Data collected will be used to highlight emerging trends in policing, which bring together public and private, local and global, actors and forces. Finally, data will be used to theorize the changing relationship between the police and the state, developing new ways to understand policing.

POR.DRECONTENT:
“Factors Influencing Police Reform and Global Police Designs” is an ethnographic study of contemporary modes of policing, which extend beyond the borders of the nation state. The research sets out to find how the interaction and interpenetration of local, national, and global police tactics, ideologies, and institutions, shape the topography of state and non-state violence in Jamaica. It looks particularly at the interaction between policing and processes of racialization, and between policing and the practice of politics.

 

The National Science Foundation Grant allowed a PhD Student, Ms. Eilat Maoz, to conduct 12 months of fieldwork in Kingston, Jamaica. The first phase of her research involved collecting ethnographic data within the Jamaica Constabulary Force, observing the daily operations of the Community Safety and Security Branch and the Criminal Investigation Branch at a police division in downtown Kingston. Data collected includes information about police interaction with publics, practices of criminal investigation, strategic decision making, and internal operations. The second phase of the research focused on the interaction between police and communities through ethnographic observations in two civil society organizations that work under the auspices of the Jamaican Ministry of National Security. Data collected in these sites focused on community-based approaches to violence and crime prevention, and on emancipatory cultural practices among the Jamaican working class. In the third phase, research was carried out in collaboration with the Independent Commission of Investigations (INDECOM), a statutory body established to investigate misuse of force by the security forces, including police-related fatalities. This phase homed in on the factors influencing police brutality in particular, their local and global histories, and conflicts between local and international stakeholders regarding the use of force. Some 50 in-depth interviews were carried out with policemen of all ranks, security consultants and professionals, policy-makers, and community members.  

 

Research findings suggest that the landscape of policing in Jamaica is shifting in response to local and global tensions. As a result of changing legal and cultural norms, a model of policing which relied on collusion between political parties, local strongmen, and the JCF to deliver social order, is becoming increasingly untenable. Yet, liberal models of policing that stress state monopoly over the use of force, public legitimacy, professionalism, and the rule of law, are yet to institutionalized in a meaningful way. We find suspicion towards the liberal policing prevalent both inside and outside of the Force, and apparent in internal and public conflicts surrounding the means and the ends of the police. We also find, and give credence to, a Jamaican critique of liberal government and liberal policing, grounded in the historical experience of slavery and colonialism. This is a critique our study seeks to elaborate.

 

From its inception, the concept of liberal policing has presupposed a society where the majority of individuals “obey freely” to the law, being so disciplined and predisposed through education, socialization, and wage labor. It assumes the constant production of rational self-governing and autonomous individuals, ideally raced and gendered as male, middle class, and white. According to liberal theories of government, it is only when the subject’s internalized relationship with the law fails—no longer providing the appropriate measure of control and obedience required by state and capital—that the police are called into action. In other words, within the coordinates of liberal rule, the cultivation of rational, self-possessive and ultimately disciplined subjects is the other side of the more repressive facets of modern power, embodied in police work.

 

Thinking about policing in the long aftermath of slavery requires re-examining the notion of freedom underlying Western theories of government. This, we contend, is precisely what the Jamaican people are doing in practice. In our study, we discuss current attempts to reform the JCF from a colonial police force to a liberal police service and show how the two arms of government—the subjectivizing (pedagogical) and the subjecting (repressive)—work in tandem. Furthermore, looking at how communities respond to different police projects, our ethnography foregrounds Jamaican cultural practices that challenge the very notions of subjectivity, self-representation, and freedom presupposed by liberal policing and government. We find practices that grapple precisely with the heart of the matter: the supposedly zero-sum game between self-discipline and external domination.

 

By ethnographically unearthing some of the anthropological presuppositions of modern policing our study contributes to the reevaluation of contemporary policing scholarship, which all too often remains trapped in the same problematic of discipline/repression or normalization/control as the police apparatuses it purports to study. Looking at the emancipatory practices of working class communities in Jamaica we also seek to restore a belief in human collective action at a time of narrowing democratic space, and explore possibilities of organizing life-in-common beyond the liberal state.
